subject: Sleep
title: Blue Light Glasses Fix Sleep
description: A micro-lesson that makes Blue Light Glasses Fix Sleep usable.

hook.text: Blue light blocking glasses are a billion-dollar industry. The evidence that they improve sleep is surprisingly thin.

buildup.text: Blue light does suppress melatonin. Melanopsin receptors in the eye are most sensitive to wavelengths around 480 nm.

discovery.text: But the amount of blue light from screens is far less than daylight and may not be the main issue.

twist.text: A 2021 meta-analysis found no significant improvement in sleep quality from blue light blocking glasses.

climax.text: The real problem with screens before bed is psychological arousal from content, not the light wavelength.

punchline.text: Blue light glasses filter the wrong problem. It's the content, not the color.

quiz.question: Do blue light blocking glasses significantly improve sleep?
options: No, a meta-analysis found no significant sleep quality improvement
They work only for people over 50
